And if it is three, which is the Jīm by both sums, and the Lām and the undotted Sīn according to some, or the dotted Shīn according to others, by the Lesser Sum, you make the Jīm your world (عالمك) and confront it with the World of Sovereignty (عالم الملك) in its aspect of sovereignty, the World of Omnipotence (عالم الجبروت) in its aspect of omnipotence, and the World of Dominion (عالم الملكوت) in its aspect of dominion. By the Lesser Sum number in the Jīm, it manifests from you; and by the Greater Sum number in it, the Lām, and the Sīn or Shīn, aspects of the sought-after reality manifest, based on <<مَن جَاءَ بِالْحَسَنَةِ فَلَهُ عَشْرُ أَمْثَالِهَا وَاللَّهُ يُضَاعِفُ لِمَن يَشَاءُ>> (Whoever comes with a good deed will have ten times the like thereof, and Allah multiplies for whom He wills), according to preparedness (الاستعداد). The lowest degree, which includes the common people, is the mentioned ten, and the multiplication depends on preparedness, wherein the men of deeds differ. Every knower is on his path in this regard. Our purpose in this book is not what God grants to the letters in terms of realities when one realizes their realities, but rather to present what God grants to the one who originates them, whether in utterance or script, when he realizes the realities of these letters and is unveiled (كوشف) to their secrets. Know this.

And if it is four, which is the Dāl by both sums, and the Mīm and Tā’ by the Lesser Sum, you make the Dāl your foundations (قواعدك) and confront it with the Essence (الذات), the Attributes (الصفات), the Acts (الأفعال), and the connections (الروابط). By the Lesser Sum number in the Dāl, the secrets of your acceptance manifest; and by the Greater Sum number in it, the Mīm, and the Tā’, aspects of the corresponding sought-after reality manifest, and the perfection (الكمال) in them, and the most perfect (الأكمل) according to preparedness.

And if it is five, which is the Hā’ by both sums, and the Nūn and Thā’ by the Lesser Sum, you make the Hā’ your kingdom (مملكتك) in the stations of the letters and the confrontation of heroes. You confront it with the five spirits (الأرواح الخمسة): the animal, the imaginative (الخيالي), the intellectual (الفكري), the rational (العقلي), and the holy (القدسي). By the Lesser Sum number in the Hā’, the secrets of your acceptance manifest; and by the Greater Sum number in it, the Nūn, and the Thā’, aspects of the corresponding sought-after reality manifest, and the perfect and the most perfect are an effect resulting from preparedness.

And if it is six, which is the Wāw by both sums, and the Ṣād or Sīn (according to the difference of opinion) and the Khā’ by the Lesser Sum, you make the Wāw your known directions (جهاتك المعلومة) and confront it with the Real (الحق) in them by one aspect, and their affirmation by another aspect, which is the science of the Form (علم الصورة). By the Lesser Sum number in the Wāw, the secrets of acceptance manifest; and by the Greater Sum number in it, the Ṣād or Sīn, and the Khā’, aspects of the corresponding sought-after reality manifest. In this Theophany (التجلي), the unveiled one (المكاشف) knows the secrets of the Equilibrium (الاستواء) and <<مَا يَكُونُ مِن نَّجْوَىٰ ثَلَاثَةٍ إِلَّا هُوَ رَابِعُهُمْ أَيْنَ مَا كُنتُمْ>> (There is no secret conversation of three except that He is the fourth of them, wherever they are), and <<وَهُوَ الَّذِي فِي السَّمَاءِ إِلَٰهٌ وَفِي الْأَرْضِ إِلَٰهٌ>> (And He is the God in the heaven and the God in the earth). Every verse or report that affirms direction (الجهة), limitation (التحديد), and measure (المقدار) for Him, Glorified and Exalted is He, and the perfection and the most perfect in it, is according to preparedness and qualification (التأهب).

And if it is seven, which is the Zāy by both sums, and the ‘Ayn and Dhāl by the Lesser Sum, you make that which is from you your attributes (صفاتك) and confront it with His Attributes (صفاته). By the Lesser Sum number in the Zāy, the secrets of your acceptance manifest; and by the Greater Sum number in it, the ‘Ayn, and the Dhāl, aspects of the corresponding sought-after reality manifest. In this Theophany, the unveiled one knows the secrets of all the Septenaries (المسبعات) wherever they occur, and the perfection and the most perfect in it are according to preparedness and qualification.

And if it is eight, which is the Ḥā’ by both sums, and the Fā’ according to one opinion, the Ṣād according to another, the Ḍād according to another, and the Ẓā’ according to another, you make the Ḥā’ your Essence (ذاتك) with all that it contains, and confront it with the Divine Presence (الحضرة الإلهية), a confrontation of the image with the mirror (صورة المرآة). By the Lesser Sum number in the Ḥā’, the secrets of your acceptance manifest; and by the Greater Sum number in it, the Fā’, the Ẓā’, or the Ḍād, aspects of the corresponding sought-after reality manifest. In this Theophany, the unveiled one knows the secrets of the eight gates of Paradise (أبواب الجنة الثمانية) and their opening for whomever God wills here, and every octagonal Presence (حضرة مثمنة) in Existence (الوجود), and the perfection and the most perfect are according to preparedness.

And if it is nine, which is the Ṭā’ by both sums, and the Ḍād or Ṣād according to one opinion, and in the hundreds the Ẓā’ or Ghayn according to one opinion, by the Lesser Sum, you make the Ṭā’ your levels (مراتبك) in Existence (الوجود) upon which you stand at the time of your contemplation in this Theophany. You confront it with the levels of the Presence (مراتب الحضرة), which is the Eternity (الأبد) for it and for you. By the Lesser Sum number in the Ṭā’, the secrets of acceptance manifest; and by the Greater Sum number in it, the Ḍād or Ṣād, and the Ghayn or Ẓā’, aspects of the corresponding sought-after reality manifest. In this Theophany, the unveiled one knows the secrets of the spiritual stations (المقامات الروحانية) and abodes (المنازلات) and the secrets of the Oneness (الأحدية). The perfect and the most perfect are according to preparedness. This is one of the aspects for which we presented the number of the letter, so act upon it. Even if there are other aspects, I wish you would act upon this one, for it is the first key (المفتاح الأول). From here, the secrets of the numbers, their spirits (أرواحها), and their abodes will be opened to you. For number is a secret among the secrets of God in Existence (الوجود), manifested in the Divine Presence (الحضرة الإلهية) potentially (بالقوة).

The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said:
"Indeed, Allah has ninety-nine Names, one hundred minus one; whoever enumerates them will enter Paradise."
And he said: "Indeed, Allah has seventy thousand veils (حجاب)."
And so on. [Number] appeared in the World (العالم) actually (بالفعل), and potentiality (القوة) was drawn along with it, so it is in the World potentially and actually. Our intention, if God grants us long life and delays the term, is to compose a work on the properties of number (خواص العدد) in which we have not been preceded in my science, revealing the secrets of numbers that their realities grant in the Divine Presence, in the World, and in the connections (الروابط), secrets by which the inner realities rejoice and through which felicity is attained in the Abode of Permanence (دار القرار).

### [Return to the Beginning: Meanings of the World of Letters]

As for our statement regarding its simple elements (بسائطه), we do not mean the simple elements of the letter's shape, such as Ṣād (ص), but rather the simple elements of the utterance (اللفظ) which is the word indicating it—that is, the Name or the Naming, which is your saying *Ṣād*. It is the simple elements of this utterance that we mean. As for the simple elements of the shape, it has no simple elements composed of letters, but it has deficiency, completeness, and addition, such as the Rā’ and Zāy being half of the Nūn, the Wāw being half of the Qāf, the Kāf being four-fifths of the Ṭā’ and four-sixths of the Ẓā’, the Dāl being two-fifths of the Ṭā’, the Yā’ being two Dhāls, and the Lām exceeding the Alif by a Nūn and the Nūn by an Alif, and similar relations. As for the simple elements of the shapes of the letters, this comes specifically from the dots (النقط). Its simple elements are according to its dots, and the elevation and descent of the stations of its dots and their spheres (أفلاكها) are according to the letter’s rank in the World, whether by its Essence (ذاته) or by an attribute it currently possesses. The spheres from which the simple elements of that mentioned letter originated, through their combination and all their movements, are what produced the utterance of it according to us. And those spheres traverse an outermost sphere according to their expansion.

As for our statement regarding its sphere (فلكه) and the years of its sphere’s movement, we mean the sphere from which the organ containing its place of articulation (مخرجه) originated. For the head of the human being was brought into existence by God the Exalted at a specific movement of a specific sphere among specific spheres. The neck originated from the sphere adjacent to this mentioned sphere, and the chest from the fourth sphere from this first mentioned sphere. Everything that exists in the head—of meanings, spirits (الأرواح), secrets, letters, and veins, and everything in the head of form and meaning—is from that sphere, and its cycle is twelve thousand years. The cycle of the neck’s sphere, and what is in it of form and meaning, including the guttural letters (الحروف الحلقية), is eleven thousand years. And the cycle of the chest’s sphere, according to what we have mentioned, is nine thousand years. Its nature (طبعه), its element (عنصره), and what originates from it, all revert to the reality of that sphere.

### [Classes (طبقات) of the World of Letters]

As for our statement that it is distinguished in such-and-such a class (طبقة), know that the World of Letters (عالم الحروف) is arranged in classes relative to the Divine Presence (الحضرة الإلهية) and proximity to it, just like us. You will recognize this among them by what I mention to you. The Divine Presence for the letters, in our witnessing (الشاهد), is only in the world of script (عالم الرقم)—the line of the Qur’anic manuscript (خط المصحف)—and in speech, it is the recitation (التلاوة), even though it flows through all speech, recited or otherwise. It is not your concern to know that every utterance spoken until eternity is the Qur’an, but in Existence (الوجود) it is equivalent to the ruling of permissibility (الإباحة) in our Law (شرعنا). Opening this door leads to great prolixity, for its field is vast. So, we have turned to a partial matter from the aspect of its small sphere, which is the inscribed (المرقوم)—the written and the specifically uttered. Know that matters, according to us, based on Unveiling (الكشف), when they manifest in Existence, the first is nobler than the second, and so on sequentially up to the middle. From the middle, the differentiation occurs like the first, up to the last. The last and the first are the noblest of what has appeared, and then they differentiate according to what they were established for and according to the station (المقام).

We looked at how the rank of the Qur’anic script is ordered according to us, by which letters the chapters (السور) begin, by which they end, and which letters are specific to the chapters unknown in theoretical knowledge but known by Divinely-imparted knowledge (العلم اللدني). We looked at the repetition of *Bismillāh al-Raḥmān al-Raḥīm* (In the Name of God, the Most Merciful, the Compassionate). We looked at the letters that are not specific to the beginning, nor the end, nor to *Bismillāh al-Raḥmān al-Raḥīm*. We asked God the Exalted to inform us whether this Divine specialization granted to these letters is a specialization of providence (عناية) without any cause, like the specialization of the Prophets with Prophethood and all primordial things, or if it is a specialization attained through acquisition (الاكتساب). This was unveiled to us through an unveiling of inspiration (كشف إلهام), and we saw it as both aspects combined: for some people, it is providence, and for others, it is a reward for what they did in the initial establishment. All of it, for us, for them, and for the World, is providence from God the Exalted. When we understood this, we designated the letters that are not established as first or last in the ranks of priority, as we shall mention, as the **General Letters (عامة الحروف)**, which have no share in this Qur’anic specialization. These are Jīm, Ḍād, Khā’, Dhāl, Ghayn, and Shīn. We designated the **First Class of the Elite (الطبقة الأولى من الخواص)** as the letters of the unknown chapters. These are Alif, Lām, Mīm, Ṣād, Rā’, Kāf, Hā’, Yā’, ‘Ayn, Ṭā’, Sīn, Ḥā’, Qāf, and Nūn. By this, I mean the form of their sharing in utterance and script. Their sharing in script is their sharing in form, and the verbal sharing is the application of a single name to them, like Zayd and another Zayd, who share the form and the name. However, what is established and known to us is that the Ṣād in *Alif Lām Mīm Ṣād*, the Ṣād in *Kāf Hā’ Yā’ ‘Ayn Ṣād*, and the Ṣād in *Ṣād* are not identical to one another, but differ according to the rulings, states, and stations of the chapter. Likewise, all these letters are in this rank, and this encompasses them verbally and graphically.

**The Second Class of the Elite (الطبقة الثانية من الخاصة)**, who are the elite of the elite, are every letter that occurs at the beginning of a chapter of the Qur’an, whether known or unknown. These are the letters Alif, Yā’, Bā’, Sīn, Kāf, Ṭā’, Qāf, Tā’, Wāw, Ṣād, Ḥā’, Nūn, Lām, Hā’, and ‘Ayn. **The Third Class of the Elite (الطبقة الثالثة من الخواص)**, who are the Quintessence (الخلاصة), are the letters occurring at the ends of the chapters, such as Nūn, Mīm, Rā’, Bā’, Dāl, Zāy, Alif, Ṭā’, Yā’, Wāw, Hā’, Ẓā’, Thā’, Lām, Fā’, and Sīn. Although the Alif appears graphically and verbally in <<رِكْزًا>> (a sound), <<لِزَامًا>> (a necessity), and <<فَمَنِ اهْتَدَىٰ>> (and whoever is guided), the Unveiling (الكشف) only granted us the letter preceding that Alif, so we stopped there and named it the last, as we witnessed there. We affirmed the Alif as we saw it here, but in another section, not this one, for we do not add to the restriction in these sections beyond what we witness. Rather, we sometimes desire to omit something from them for fear of prolixity, so we suffice in that regard by means of the script and the utterance, and we provide an utterance that encompasses those meanings whose expressions were numerous, and we deliver it without violating any part of the delivery, nor do we omit anything, and the initial prolixity does not appear, so the desired end is achieved, praise be to God. **The Fourth Class of the Elite (الطبقة الرابعة من الخواص)**, who are the Purity of the Quintessence (صفاء الخلاصة), are the letters of *Bismillāh al-Raḥmān al-Raḥīm*. I only mentioned it where the Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him, mentioned it, according to the limit God mentioned it to him by the two aspects of revelation. This is the revelation of the Qur’an, which is the first revelation. For, according to us, through Unveiling, the Criterion (الفرقان) came to the Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him, as a summarized Qur’an (قرآنا مجملا), not detailed in verses and chapters. This is why he, peace be upon him, used to hasten with it when Gabriel, peace be upon him, brought him the Criterion. So, he was told: <<وَلَا تَعْجَلْ بِالْقُرْآنِ>> (And do not hasten with [recitation of] the Qur’an) which you have, delivering it summarized so that it is not understood from you, <<مِن قَبْلِ أَن يُقْضَىٰ إِلَيْكَ وَحْيُهُ>> (before its revelation is completed to you) as a detailed Criterion, and <<وَقُل رَّبِّ زِدْنِي عِلْمًا>> (And say, "My Lord, increase me in knowledge") by detailing what I have summarized in the meanings. He alluded to this from the door of secrets when He said: <<إِنَّا أَنزَلْنَاهُ فِي لَيْلَةٍ>> (Indeed, We sent it down during a night), and He did not say *part* of it. Then He said: <<فِيهَا يُفْرَقُ كُلُّ أَمْرٍ حَكِيمٍ>> (In that night is made distinct every precise matter). This is the revelation of the Criterion (وحي الفرقان), which is the second aspect of the two aspects. The discussion of *Bismillāh al-Raḥmān al-Raḥīm* will come in the chapter dedicated to it in this book. Know that the *Basmala* of Sūrat Barā’ah is the one found in Sūrat al-Naml. For when the Real (الحق) the Exalted grants something, He does not retract it or return it to non-existence. When the mercy of *Barā’ah* (the *Basmala*) was removed, the ruling of disavowal (التبري) from its people necessitated the removal of mercy from them. The angel stood with it, not knowing where to place it, because every human nation had already taken its mercy through its belief in its prophet. So, he said: "Give this *Basmala* to the beasts (البهائم) that believed in Solomon, peace be upon him, for they are not obligated to believe except in their own messenger." When they recognized the stature of Solomon and believed in him, they were given a share of human mercy, which is *Bismillāh al-Raḥmān al-Raḥīm*, which was stripped from the polytheists. In this chapter is the spy (الجساسة). **The Fifth Class (الطبقة الخامسة)**, which is the very Purity of the Quintessence (عين صفاء الخلاصة), is the letter Bā’. It is the foremost letter because it is the beginning of the *Basmala* in every chapter, and the chapter that did not contain the *Basmala* began with the Bā’, as the Exalted said: <<بَرَاءَةٌ>> (Disavowal). One of the Israelites, one of their rabbis, said to us: "You have no share in Unity (التوحيد) because the chapters of your book begin with the Bā’." I replied: "Nor do you, for the beginning of the Torah is Bā’." He was silenced. Only this is possible, for the Alif never begins anything essentially. Whatever of these letters occurred at the beginning of the chapters, we said it has the beginning of the Path (بداية الطريق). Whatever occurred at the end, we said it has the goal of the Path (غاية الطريق). If it is from the General Letters, we said it has the middle of the Path, because the Qur’an is the Straight Path (الصراط المستقيم).

### [Levels (مراتب), Movements (حركاتها), and Realities (حقائقها) of the Letters]

As for our statement regarding its rank being the second up to the seventh, we mean by that the simple elements (بسائط) of these letters that share in the numbers. The Nūn has two simple elements in Divinity (الألوهية). The Mīm has three simple elements in the Human (الإنسان). The Jīm, Wāw, Kāf, and Qāf have four simple elements in the Jinn. The Dhāl, Zāy, Ṣād, ‘Ayn, Ḍād, Sīn, Dhāl, Ghayn, and Shīn have five simple elements in the Beasts (البهائم). The Alif, Hā’, and Lām have six simple elements in the Plants (النبات). The Bā’, Ḥā’, Ṭā’, Yā’, Fā’, Rā’, Tā’, Thā’, Khā’, and Ẓā’ have seven simple elements in the Inanimate (الجماد).

As for our statement regarding its movement being crooked (معوجة), straight (مستقيمة), inverted (منكوسة), mixed (ممتزجة), or horizontal (أفقية): By the straight movement, I mean every letter that directs the spiritual aspiration (الهمة) specifically toward the side of the Real (الحق)—from the aspect of negation if you are a knower, and from the aspect of what is witnessed if you are a witnesser (مشاهد). The inverted movement is every letter that directs the aspiration toward the Cosmos (الكون) and its secrets. The crooked movement, which is the horizontal, is every letter that directs the aspiration toward the connection of the Creator (المكون) with the created (المكون). The mixed movement is every letter that directs the aspiration toward the knowledge of two or more of the matters I have mentioned to you. This appears in the script in the Alif, the Mīm with the tail, the Ḥā’, the Nūn, and similar letters.

As for our statement that it has the Heights (الأعراف), Creation (الخلق), States (الأحوال), and Miraculous Gifts (الكرامات), or the Realities (الحقائق), Stations (المقامات), and Descendings (المنازلات): Know that a thing is only known by its face, meaning its reality (حقيقته). Everything by which a thing is known is its face. The dot (نقط) of the letter is its face by which it is known. The dots are of two types: dots above the letter and dots below it. If a thing has nothing by which it is known, it is known by itself through witnessing (مشاهدة) and by its opposite through transmission (نقلا)—these are the undotted letters (الحروف اليابسة). When the sphere revolves—that is, the sphere of Gnosis (فلك المعارف)—the letters dotted from above originate from it. When the sphere of Deeds (فلك الأعمال) revolves, the letters dotted from below originate from it. When the sphere of Witnessing (فلك المشاهدة) revolves, the dry, undotted letters originate from it. The sphere of Gnosis grants Creation, States, and Miraculous Gifts. The sphere of Deeds grants Realities, Stations, and Descendings. The sphere of Witnessing grants immunity (البراءة) from all of this. Abu Yazid was asked, "How are you this morning?" He replied, "I have neither morning nor evening. Morning and evening belong only to one who is bound by an attribute (الصفة), and I have no attribute." This is the station of the Heights (مقام الأعراف).

As for our statement regarding pure (خالص) or mixed (ممتزج): The pure letter is that which originates from a single element (عنصر واحد), and the mixed is that which originates from two elements or more. As for our statement regarding complete (كامل) or deficient (ناقص): The complete letter is that which originated from the completion of its sphere’s cycle, and the deficient is that which originated from part of its sphere’s cycle, where a defect occurred in the sphere that halted it, causing it to fall short of what the completion of its cycle would grant—like the worm in the animal kingdom which has only the sense of touch, and its nourishment comes from its touch, such as the Wāw with the Qāf, and the Zāy with the Nūn. As for our statement that it elevates the one connected to it, we mean every letter whose secret you grasp, and you are granted the realization (التحقق) of it and union (الاتحاد) with it, you become distinguished in the Higher World (العالم العلوي).

### [The Sanctified Letters (الحروف المقدسة)]

As for our statement regarding sanctified (مقدس), meaning sanctified from attachment to anything other than itself: It does not connect in script with another letter, but other letters connect to it. It is pure in Essence (منزه الذات). Six spheres of high apogee sustain it, from which the directions originated. These six letters are a great ocean whose depth cannot be fathomed, and whose reality is known only to God. They are the keys to the Unseen (مفاتح الغيب). We perceive, through Unveiling (الكشف), the effect linked to them. These are Alif, Wāw, Dāl, Dhāl, Rā’, and Zāy.

As for our statement regarding single (مفرد), paired (مثنى), triple (مثلث), quadruple (مربع), familiar (مؤنس), and alienated (موحش): By single up to quadruple, we mean what we shall mention. Some of the spheres from which these letters originate have a single cycle, and that is our statement of single. Two cycles is the paired, and so on up to the quadruple. As for the familiar and the alienated: The cycle becomes familiar with its sister; a thing is familiar with its form. The Exalted said: <<لِتَسْكُنُوا إِلَيْهَا وَجَعَلَ بَيْنَكُمْ مَوَدَّةً وَرَحْمَةً>> (That you may find tranquility in them; and He placed between you affection and mercy). The Gnostic (العارف) becomes familiar with the state (الحال) and finds comfort in it. The Prophet, peace be upon him, was called out to during his Night Journey (إسراؤه) in his state of alienation (استيحاشه) in the voice of Abu Bakr, and he found comfort in Abu Bakr’s voice. The Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him, and Abu Bakr were created from a single clay. Muhammad, peace and blessings be upon him, preceded, and Abu Bakr followed, <<ثَانِيَ اثْنَيْنِ إِذْ هُمَا فِي الْغَارِ إِذْ يَقُولُ لِصَاحِبِهِ لَا تَحْزَنْ إِنَّ اللَّهَ مَعَنَا>> (The second of two, when they were in the cave and he said to his companion, "Do not grieve; indeed Allah is with us"). Their speech was His speech, Glorified is He. He did not count the rank, but transferred the address to the other rank, saying, as if starting anew while connecting to this discourse: <<مَا يَكُونُ مِن نَّجْوَىٰ ثَلَاثَةٍ إِلَّا هُوَ رَابِعُهُمْ>> (There is no secret conversation of three except that He is the fourth of them). He sent it forth, and some people cut it off, and some connected it. In this is the station of affirmation (الإثبات), the subsistence of the trace (بقاء الرسم), the manifestation of the entity (ظهور العين), the sovereignty of the realities (سلطان الحقائق), and the execution of justice (العدل) from the door of grace and bounty. The alienated (الموحش) is effacement (محو), not obliteration (محق), belonging to one whose defect ascends, so realize what we have mentioned.

As for our statement that it has the Essence (الذات), the Attributes (الصفات), and the Acts (الأفعال) according to the aspects: Any letter that has one aspect has one Presence (حضرة واحدة) from these Presences—that is, one thing—according to its elevation and descent. Likewise, if the aspects are multiple. As for our statement that it has letters, I only mean the realities (الحقائق) that complete its Essence from a certain perspective. As for our statement that it has Names, we mean the Divine Names (الأسماء الإلهية), which are the primordial realities (الحقائق القديمة) from which the realities of the simple elements of that letter alone appeared. These have many high-ranking benefits for the Gnostics (العارفين). If they wish to realize them, they move Existence (الوجود) from beginning to end. For them, they are specific here, but general in the Hereafter. By them, the believer in Paradise says to the thing he desires, "Be," and it is. These are brief excerpts of the meanings of the World of Letters, presented in the most concise and briefest way possible, containing an alert for the people of spiritual scents (الروائح) and taste (الذوق). The Seventh Part is concluded, and praise belongs to God.

### [Chapter Two: On the Knowledge of the Movements (الحركات) that Distinguish Words (الكلمات), which are the Lesser Letters (الحروف الصغار)]
(In the Name of God, the Most Merciful, the Compassionate)

> The movements of the letters are six, and from them,
> God manifested the words (الكلمات) like them.
> They are *raf‘* (raising), then *naṣb* (installing), and *khafḍ* (lowering),
> Movements for the inflected letters (الأحرف المعربات).
> And they are *fatḥ* (opening), then *ḍamm* (joining), and *kasr* (breaking),
> Movements for the fixed letters (الأحرف الثابتات).
> And the fundamentals of speech are omission, which is death,
> Or quiescence (سكون) that results from movements.
> This is the state of the worlds (العوالم), so look
> At a strange life within the inanimate (موات).

### [Letters are to Words as Elements are to Bodies]

Know, may God support us and you with a spirit from Him, that we had stipulated that we would discuss the movements (الحركات) in the chapter on letters, but I did not call them the Lesser Letters (الحروف الصغار). Then we saw that there is no benefit in mixing the world of movements with the World of Letters (عالم الحروف) except after the ordering of the letters and the joining of some to others, thereby forming a word (كلمة) among the Words (الكلم). Their ordering refers to His saying, the Exalted, concerning our creation: <<فَإِذَا سَوَّيْتُهُ وَنَفَخْتُ فِيهِ مِن رُّوحِي>> (And when I have proportioned him and breathed into him of My Spirit). This is the occurrence of the movements upon these letters after their proportioning, establishing another creation called a word, just as a single person among us is called a human being. Thus, the world of words (الكلمات) and utterances (الألفاظ) originated from the World of Letters. The letters are the materials for the words, like water, earth, fire, and air are for the establishment of the creation of our bodies. Then the command-spirit (الروح الأمري) was breathed into it, and it became a human being. Just as the winds, when prepared, accepted the breathing of the command-spirit and became Jinn (جان). Just as the lights, when prepared, accepted the breathing of the spirit and became the Angels (الملائكة). Some of the Words resemble the human being, and these are the majority. And some resemble the Angels and the Jinn—both of which are Jinn—and these are the minority, such as the *Bā’* of lowering (*Bā’* al-Khafḍ), the *Lām* of lowering and emphasis, the *Wāw* of oath, its *Bā’* and *Tā’*, the *Wāw* of conjunction, its *Fā’*, and the *Qāf* of *Qāf* (commanding protection), the *Shīn* of *Shīn* (commanding slander), and the *‘Ayn* of *‘Ayn* (commanding awareness) when you command with them from *al-wiqāyah* (protection), *al-washy* (slander), and *al-wa‘y* (awareness). Everything other than this singular type is most similar to the human being. Even if the singular type resembles the inner reality of the human being, for the inner reality of the human being is truly Jinn. Since the world of movements only exists after the existence of the entities moved by them—which are the words created from the letters—we postponed the discussion of them from the chapter on letters to the chapter on utterances. Since the words we intended to mention in this chapter are part of the totality of utterances, we wished to discuss utterances in general, delimit their world, and the relation of these movements to them, after first discussing movements in general. Then, after that, we will discuss the movements specific to words, which are the movements of the tongue and their signs, which are the movements of the script. Then, after that, we will discuss the words that suggest anthropomorphism, as we mentioned.

You might say that this singular world of letters, which accepts movement without composition, such as the *Bā’* of lowering and similar singular letters, you should have attached it to the letters due to its singularity, since this is the door of composition, which is the words. We reply: The spirit—the spirits of the movements—was not breathed into the *Bā’* of lowering and its likes among the singular letters so that they might subsist by themselves, as the World of Letters subsisted alone without movements. Rather, the spirit was breathed into it for the sake of something else, so it is composite. Therefore, it does not grant that meaning until it is added to something else, as in saying: *billāh* (by God), *tallāh* (by God), and *wallāh* (by God), *la-a‘budanna* (I shall surely worship), *sa-a‘budu* (I shall worship), <<اقْنُتِي لِرَبِّكِ وَاسْجُدِي>> (Be obedient to your Lord and prostrate), and similar examples. It has no meaning when isolated other than its own meaning. These realities that arise from composition exist with its existence and cease with its cessation. The reality of the animal (الحيوان) never exists except when discrete realities, intelligible in themselves, are combined: corporeality, nourishment, and sensation. When the body, nourishment, and sensation are combined, the reality of the animal appears; it is neither the body alone, nor the nourishment alone, nor the sensation alone. If you drop the reality of sensation and combine the body and nourishment, you say 'plant,' a reality that is not the first. Since the singular letters we mentioned are influential in this other verbal composition that we have constructed to manifest realities that are not intelligible to the listener except through them, we likened them for you to the one who connects with the spiritual world (العالم الروحاني), like the Jinn. Do you not see that the human being acts between four realities: a self-reality (حقيقة ذاتية), a Lordly reality (حقيقة ربانية), a Satanic reality (حقيقة شيطانية), and angelic realities (حقائق ملكية)? A full mention of these realities will come in the chapter on the knowledge of thoughts (الخواطر) in this book. In the world of words, this is the entry of one of these letters into the world of words, creating in it what its reality grants. So understand this—may God grant us and you understanding of the secrets of His Words.

A Point and an Indication

The Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "I have been granted the comprehensive words (جوامع الكلم)." The Exalted said: <<وَكَلِمَتُهُ أَلْقَاهَا إِلَىٰ مَرْيَمَ>> (And His word which He directed to Mary). And He said: <<وَصَدَّقَتْ بِكَلِمَاتِ رَبِّهَا وَكُتُبِهِ>> (And she believed in the words of her Lord and His books). It is said: "The prince cut off the hand of the thief," and "The prince struck the robber." Whoever casts something by his command, he is the one who cast it. Thus, the caster, Muhammad, peace be upon him, cast forth from God the Words (كلمات) of the entire World (العالم) without exception of anything whatsoever. Some of it he cast forth by himself, such as the spirits of the Angels and most of the Higher World (العالم العلوي). And some of it he cast forth by His command, so the thing originates through great intermediaries. Agriculture does not reach the point where a spirit that glorifies and magnifies runs through your limbs except after many cycles (أدوار) and transitions in a world, transforming in every world of its genus into the form of its individuals. All of this reverts to the one who was granted the comprehensive words. He breathed the Israfilian Reality (الحقيقة الإسرافيلية) from the Muhammadan Reality (المحمدية) attributed to the Real (الحق)—He breathed it, as the Exalted said: *wa yawma tunfakhu fī al-ṣūri* (And the Day the Horn is blown) with a *nūn*, and it is also read with a *yā’*, a *ḍammah* on the *yā’*, and a *fatḥah* on the *fā’*. The blower is none other than Israfil, peace be upon him, yet God attributed the blowing to Himself. Thus, the blowing is from Israfil, and the acceptance is from the Horn (الصور), and the secret of the Real (سر الحق) between them is the meaning between the blower and the acceptor, like the connector (الرابط) among the letters between two words. That is the secret of the Most Holy, Most Pure Act (الفعل الأقدس الأنزه) which neither the blower nor the acceptor perceives. The blower must blow, the fire must ignite, and the lamp must be extinguished. The ignition and extinction are by the Divine Secret. So He breathed into it, and it became a bird by God’s permission. The Exalted said: <<وَنُفِخَ فِي الصُّورِ فَصَعِقَ مَن فِي السَّمَاوَاتِ وَمَن فِي الْأَرْضِ إِلَّا مَن شَاءَ اللَّهُ ثُمَّ نُفِخَ فِيهِ أُخْرَىٰ فَإِذَا هُمْ قِيَامٌ يَنظُرُونَ>> (And the Horn will be blown, and whoever is in the heavens and whoever is on the earth will fall dead, except whom Allah wills. Then it will be blown again, and immediately they will be standing, looking). The blowing is one, and the blower is one, and the difference lies in the recipient of the blowing, according to preparedness (الاستعداد). The Divine Secret remains hidden between them in every state. So pay attention, O our brothers, to this Divine matter, and know that <<إِنَّ اللَّهَ عَزِيزٌ حَكِيمٌ>> (Indeed, Allah is Exalted in Might and Wise). No one can ever reach the knowledge of the essence of Divinity (كنه الألوهة), nor is it fitting for it to be comprehended. Exalted and greatly elevated is He. The entire World, from beginning to end, is bound, part to part, worshipping part of itself. Their gnosis (معرفتهم) is from them to them, and their realities emanate from them by the Divine Secret which they do not perceive, and return to them. Glory be to Him whose sovereignty is unrivaled and whose beneficence is unmatched. <<لَا إِلَٰهَ إِلَّا هُوَ الْعَزِيزُ الْحَكِيمُ>> (There is no deity except Him, the Exalted in Might, the Wise).

### [The Confinement of Speech to Essence, Event, and Connector]

After understanding the comprehensive words (جوامع الكلم), which is the encompassing knowledge (العلم الإحاطي) and the Divine Light (النور الإلهي) specific to the secret of Existence (سر الوجود), the pillar of the dome, the leg of the Throne, and the cause of the permanence of every permanent thing—Muhammad, peace and blessings be upon him—know, may God grant you success, that the comprehensive words from the World of Letters are three: an Essence (ذات) that is rich and subsists by itself; an Essence that is poor (فقيرة) toward this rich one and does not subsist by itself, but returns to the rich Essence as an attribute (وصف) by which it is characterized, seeking it by its own essence, for it is not of its essence except by the rich Essence accompanying it—thus, poverty is also established for the rich Essence subsisting by itself, just as it is established for the other; and a third Essence that is a connector (رابطة) between two rich Essences, or two poor Essences, or a poor Essence and a rich Essence. This connecting Essence is necessarily poor toward the existence of those two Essences. Thus, poverty and need are established for all Essences, insofar as some are dependent on others, even if the aspects differ, such that absolute richness (الغني على الإطلاق) is only valid for God the Exalted, the Rich, the Praiseworthy, by virtue of His Essence (ذاته). Let us call the rich one **Essence (ذات)**, the poor Essence **Event (حدث)**, and the third Essence **Connector (رابطة)**. Thus, we say that speech (الكلم) is confined to three realities: Essence, Event, and Connector. These three are the comprehensive words. Under the genus of Essence fall many types of essences, and likewise under the genus of the word Event and Connector. We do not need to detail these types and their course in this book, as the discussion of these types has been expanded upon in our commentary on the Qur’an. If you wish to draw an analogy to what we have mentioned, look at the discourse of the grammarians (النحويين) and their division of speech into Noun (الاسم), Verb (الفعل), and Particle (الحرف), and likewise the logicians (المنطقيين). The Noun for them is the Essence for us, the Verb for them is the Event for us, and the Particle for them is the Connector for us. Some of the Events for them—indeed, all of them—are Nouns, such as standing (*al-qiyām*), sitting (*al-qu‘ūd*), and striking (*al-ḍarb*). They made the Verb every word restricted by a specific time. We, however, intended by the words to follow the realities as they are, so we made *al-qiyām* (standing), *qāma* (he stood), *yaqūmu* (he stands), and *qum* (stand!) an Event, distinguishing between them by the vague and the specific time.

### [Al-Zajjaji's Theory of the Infinitive (المصدر)]

Al-Zajjaji realized this and said: "The Event (الحدث), which is, for example, standing (*al-qiyām*), is the infinitive (المصدر)." He means that it is what emanated from the originator (المحدث), and it is the verbal noun (اسم الفعل). He means that the word *al-qiyām* is the name for this specific movement from this moving entity, by which it is called 'standing.' That posture is what is called *qiyām* (standing) when considering its state of existence, and *qāma* (he stood) when considering its state of cessation and non-existence, and *yaqūmu* (he stands) and *qum* (stand!) when considering the supposition of its occurrence. It never exists except in a moving entity, so it does not subsist by itself. Then he said: "And the verb"—meaning the utterance *qāma* and *yaqūmu*, not the act itself emanating from the moving entity, such as standing—"is derived from it." The pronoun refers to the verbal noun, which is *al-qiyām*. He means that *qāma* and *yaqūmu* are taken from *al-qiyām*, because for him, the indefinite (النكرة) precedes the definite (المعرفة). The vague is indefinite, and the specific is definite. *Al-qiyām* is temporally vague, while *qāma* is temporally specific (even if *an* enters upon it), and *yaqūmu* is temporally specific (even if *lam* enters upon it). This is the doctrine of those who hold that analysis (التحليل) is a branch of composition (التركيب), and that the composite existed as composite. It is also the doctrine of those who hold to differentiation (التفريق) and that composition is accidental, which is more supported in the realm of transmission (النقل). For it is more apparent that the definite precedes the indefinite, and that the word *Zayd* was only established for a specific person, and then indefiniteness occurred because others shared that utterance, necessitating definition by description, apposition, and the like. Thus, the definite is prior to the indefinite according to the Realizers (المحققين), even if those others have an aspect that is more appropriate to them.

### [Corporeal (الجسمانية) and Spiritual (الروحانية) Movements]

As for us, and those who follow our course and ascend our lofty ascent, our objective is another matter, which is not the absolute doctrine of either of the two groups, except with relations, attributions, and consideration of aspects whose mention would be lengthy and are not needed in this book, as we have mentioned them in other compositions of ours. Let us clarify that movements are of two types: corporeal movement (حركة جسمانية) and spiritual movement (حركة روحانية). Corporeal movement has many types, which will be mentioned later in the book, and likewise the spiritual. In this book, we only need the movements of speech, both utterance and script. The movements of the script are like the bodies, and the verbal movements are like the spirits (الأرواح) for them. Moving entities are of two types: established (متمكن) and colored/changing (متلون). The changing entity is every moving entity that moves with all movements or some of them. The one that moves with all of them is like the Dāl of *Zayd*. The one that moves with some of them is like the indeclinable nouns (الاسماء التي لا تنصرف) in their state of indeclinability, for they may become declinable in indefiniteness and annexation, like the Dāl of *Aḥmad*. The established entity is every moving entity that remains fixed on one movement and does not shift from it, like the indeclinable nouns (الاسماء المبنية) such as *hā’ulā’i* and *ḥadhāmi*, and like the letters of the declinable nouns that precede the letter of inflection, such as the Zāy and Yā’ of *Zayd* and its like. Know that the spheres of the movements are the spheres of the letters upon which those movements occur verbally and graphically; look for it there. They have simple elements, states, and stations, just as the letters did, which we will mention in the book *Al-Mabādi’* (The Principles) dedicated to the science of letters, God willing. Just as coloration (التلوين) and fixity (التمكين) are established for the Essence, they are also established for the Event and the Connector, but in the raising (*raf‘*), installing (*naṣb*), omission of the description, and omission of the trace. The coloration of the composition of the Connector occurs for three reasons: agreement (الموافقة), metaphor (الاستعارة), and necessity (الاضطرار). By agreement, which is following: *ibnum* (son) in the nominative, *ibnama* in the accusative, and *ibnim* in the genitive. By metaphor: the movement of transference, like the movement of the Dāl in <<قَدْ أَفْلَحَ>> (He has succeeded) in the recitation of those who transfer it. By necessity: the vocalization due to the meeting of two quiescent letters. The movement of conforming agreement may occur in the essential composition, even though the origin of all letters is fixity (التمكين), which is indeclinability (البناء), like the primordial nature (*fiṭra*) within us. Here are secrets for those who pay attention, but the parents transfer away from the restricted primordial nature, not the absolute primordial nature. Likewise, the letters are fixed in their station, they do not fail, they are established, all quiescent in their state. The speaker wished to convey what was in his soul to the listener, so he needed coloration (التلوين), and thus moved the sphere from which the movements originate, according to Abu Talib. According to others, the sphere is prior, and the utterance or script is from that sphere. This is a point of seeking for those who desire the direct witnessing of realities.

### [The Primordial Realities (الحقائق الأول) and their Higher Orientations]

As for us, we do not restrict ourselves to the doctrine of Abu Talib, nor do we restrict ourselves to the doctrine of the other, for each of them spoke the truth from a certain aspect but did not complete it. I say that the primordial Divine Realities (الحقائق الأول الإلهية) orient themselves toward the higher spheres (الأفلاك العلوية) in the same way they orient themselves toward the loci of their effects, according to those other than Abu Talib al-Makki. Each reality accepts according to its rank. Since those spheres, according to those other than Abu Talib, are closer to the realities in subtlety (اللطافة), their acceptance was swifter due to the absence of preoccupation and the purity of the locus from the turbidities of attachments, for it is pure. Therefore, he made it the effective cause. If this speaker knew that those primordial realities only oriented themselves toward what suits them in subtlety, which is the breaths of the human being (أنفاس الإنسان), then the higher sphere that suits the world of breaths is moved—and this is the doctrine of Abu Talib. Then that higher sphere moves the desired organ for the desired purpose, through the suitability between them. For the higher sphere, though subtle, is at the first degree of density (الكثافة) and the last degree of subtlety (اللطافة), unlike the world of our breaths. The doctrines have converged, for disagreement is not valid according to us or in our Path (طريقنا). But he is an unveiled one (كاشف), so unveil, and you will understand what we have indicated and realize it, for it is a wondrous secret among the greatest Divine Secrets. Abu Talib alluded to it in his book *Al-Qūt*.

### [Coloration (التلوين) and Fixity (التمكين) in the World of Letters]

Then we return and say: The speaker needed coloration (التلوين) to reach his objective, and he found the World of Letters and Movements receptive to what he desired from them, knowing that they would not depart from their state nor would their reality be nullified. Thus, the speaker imagines that he has changed the letter, but he has not changed it. The proof of this is that if you annihilate your contemplation in the Dāl of *Zayd* insofar as it is Dāl, and you look at it insofar as *qāma* (he stood) precedes it, for example, and you devote yourself to it, or any verbal verb that might originate from it, only the nominative (*raf‘*) is valid for it specifically. Thus, it has not departed from the fixity (بنائه) upon which it was found. Whoever imagines that the Dāl of the subject is the Dāl of the object or the Dāl of the genitive has confused matters and believed that the first word is the very entity of the second, not its likeness. Whoever believes this in Existence (الوجود) has strayed from correctness. Perhaps something from this chapter on utterances will come if it is decreed and inspired to us. It has become clear to you that the origin for everything is fixity (الثبوت). Do you not see that the reality of the servant’s fixity and establishment (تمكنه) is only in servitude (*‘ubūdiyya*)? If he is characterized one day by a Lordly attribute (وصف رباني), do not say that it is borrowed by him. Rather, look at the reality that accepted that attribute from him; you will find it fixed in that attribute. Whenever its entity appears, it is adorned with that adornment. Beware of saying that this has departed from its proper sphere by the attribute of its Lord, for God the Exalted did not strip His attribute and give it to him. Rather, the confusion occurred in both the utterance and the meaning for the non-Realizer (غير المحقق), who says, "This is this." We know that this is not this, and this is fitting for this, and not fitting for that. So, let it be a loan and a trust for the one for whom it is not fitting. This is a deficiency and the discourse of one who is blind to the realization of realities, for this is necessarily fitting for this. The Lord is not the servant, even if it is said of God, Glorified is He, that He is Knower (*‘ālim*), and it is said of the servant that he is Knower, and likewise Living, Willing, Hearing, Seeing, and all other Attributes and perceptions. Beware of making the life of the Real (حياة الحق) the life of the servant in definition, lest impossibilities become necessary for you. If you make the life of the Lord according to what Lordship deserves, and the life of the servant according to what the Cosmos deserves, then it is fitting for the servant to be living. If that were not fitting for him, it would not be valid for the Real to be a Commander or a Dominator except over Himself. And He is exalted above being commanded or dominated. If it is established that the commanded and the dominated must be another matter and another entity, then he must be living, knowing, willing, and established in what is willed for him. This is what the realities grant. Accordingly, there is a letter that accepts only one movement, like the Hā’ of *hādhā* (this). And there is a letter that accepts two or three movements from the aspect of its corporeal and spiritual form, like the Hā’ in the pronoun: *lahu* (to him), *lahā* (to her), and *bihi* (by him). Just as you accept shyness in your soul and its redness in your form, and you accept anxiety in your soul and its paleness in your form. The garment accepts different colors. The only remaining point of Unveiling is concerning the reality that accepts accidents: Is it one, or is its status the status of accidents in non-existence and existence? This is a topic for the speculative thinkers (النظار). As for us, we do not need it and do not pay attention to it, for it is a deep ocean whose knowledge, through Unveiling, is easy for the seeker (المريد), but difficult through rational thought (العقل).

### [The Researcher of Utterance and the Informer of Realization]

Then I return and say that when the letter [or word] establishes the Reality of Agency (حقيقة الفاعلية) by emptying the act onto the specific structure in the language, you say, "Allah said." And when the reality of seeking is established in it, it is then called *mansūb* (accusative) by the verb, or *maf'ūl* (object), as you wish. This is by you seeking aid from Him or intending Him, just as He sought from me the performance of what He obligated me to do. Because He did not give me except after my asking, my asking—or my state (حال) that stood in place of my asking due to His promise—caused Him to give me. He, the Exalted, said: <<وَكَانَ حَقًّا عَلَيْنَا نَصْرُ الْمُؤْمِنِينَ>> (And it was incumbent upon Us to support the believers). So my asking Him is from His command to me to do so, and His giving me is from my seeking it from Him. Thus you say, "I called upon Allah," making the letter *hā* accusative, though it had been nominative. Thus, we know by the vocalizations (الحركات) that the realities (الحقائق) have differed. By this, the convention (الاصطلاح) is established in the grammatical error of some people. This is when the speaker is other than us. As for the Speaker, He knows the realities first and causes them to run in their spheres (أفلاكها) according to what they necessitate, considering specific spheres. Every speaker is of this rank, even if he does not know this detail, for he is knowledgeable of it from the perspective that he does not know that he is knowledgeable of it. This is because the things spoken are either a word (لفظ) that indicates a meaning—which is the station of the one investigating the word, asking what its indication is, so that he may see what meanings the speaker intended—or it is a meaning (معنى) indicated by a certain word—which is the one who informs about what has been realized. We disregard the grammatical error, for its spheres are other than these spheres. The omission of vocalizations from the script for some people but not others—what is its cause and where does it come from? All this is in the *Kitāb al-Mabādī* (Book of Principles), since the intention of this book is brevity and conciseness to the utmost extent. If you were to be informed of the realities as we have been informed of them, and of the world of spirits (الأرواح) and meanings (المعاني), you would see every reality, spirit, and meaning in its proper level (مرتبته). So understand and adhere to this. Here we have mentioned some of what the realities of the vocalizations yield that is appropriate for this book. Let us now rein in the discourse and return to the knowledge of the words we mentioned, such as the word *Istiwā’* (Settling/Ascending), *Ayn* (Where), *Fī* (In), *Kāna* (Was), Laughter, Joy, Smiling, Wonder, Weariness, Companionship (Ma'iyya), Eye, Hand, Foot, Face, Form (الصورة), Transformation, Wrath, Modesty, Prayer, Emptiness, and what has been transmitted in the Glorious Book [the Quran] and the Hadith concerning these expressions that suggest anthropomorphism (التشبيه) and corporealization (التجسيم), and other things that are inappropriate for Allah the Exalted according to intellectual consideration, especially by the intellect. So we say:

### The Expressions that Suggest Anthropomorphism and Corporealization in the Glorious Quran and the Prophetic Hadith

Since the Quran was revealed in the language of the Arabs, it contains what is in the Arabic language. And since the Bedouins do not comprehend what is incomprehensible unless it is brought down to them, in terms of communication, to what they can comprehend, these words came in this manner. As He said: <<ثُمَّ دَنَا فَتَدَلَّى فَكَانَ قَابَ قَوْسَيْنِ أَوْ أَدْنَىٰ>> (Then he approached and descended, and was at a distance of two bow-lengths or nearer). Since kings among the Arabs would seat their honored, close servant at this measure of distance, they understood from this address the nearness of Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him) to his Lord, and they did not care about anything they understood from that except the nearness. The intellectual proof (البرهان العقلي) negates limit and distance, until the discussion on the transcendence (تنزيه) of the Creator from the anthropomorphism suggested by these expressions comes in the third chapter, which follows this chapter.

### Divisions of Expression According to the Arabs

Since expressions among the Arabs are of four divisions: 1. Disparate expressions (ألفاظ متباينة), which are names that do not exceed their referent, such as *al-baḥr* (sea), *al-miftāḥ* (key), and *al-miqṣān* (scissors). 2. Homogeneous expressions (ألفاظ متواطئة), which is every word agreed upon to be applied to individuals of a certain type, such as *al-rajul* (man) and *al-mar'a* (woman). 3. Shared expressions (ألفاظ مشتركة), which is every word of a single form applied to different meanings, such as *al-'ayn* (eye/spring/essence), *al-mushtarī* (Jupiter/buyer), and *al-insān* (human/pupil of the eye). 4. Synonymous expressions (ألفاظ مترادفة), which are words of different forms applied to a single meaning, such as *al-asad*, *al-hizbar*, and *al-ghaḍanfar* (all meaning lion); and *al-sayf*, *al-ḥusām*, and *al-ṣārim* (all meaning sword); and *al-khamr*, *al-raḥīq*, *al-ṣahbā’*, and *al-khandarīs* (all meaning wine). These are the primary categories (الأمهات), like coldness, heat, dryness, and wetness in the natures (الطبائع). Then there are ambiguous, metaphorical, transferred, and other expressions, all of which return to these primary categories by convention (بالاصطلاح). For the ambiguous, even if you say it is a fifth category of expressions—such as *al-nūr* (light), which is applied to the known and to Knowledge (العلم) due to the similarity of Knowledge to it, in that the eye of insight (عين البصيرة) unveils the known by it, just as light unveils the sensible visible object to the sight. Since this similarity is sound, Knowledge is called light, and it is annexed to the shared expressions. Thus, no expression is detached from these primary categories. This is the limit for every investigator in this chapter. As for us, we agree with them on this, but we have additions based on our insight into the realities (الحقائق) from a perspective they have not accessed. From this, we know that all expressions are disparate (متباينة), even if they share pronunciation; and from another perspective, all of them are shared (مشتركة), even if they are disparate in pronunciation. We have alluded to something of this previously in this chapter, at the end of the section on letters.

### The Realizer and the Tools of Restriction: Keys to Treasures

When this is clear, know, O intimate friend (ولي حميم), that the Realizer (المحقق), the Gnostic (العارف) who stands firm in what the Divine Presence (الحضرة الإلهية) necessitates of sanctification (التقديس), transcendence (التنزيه), and the negation of likeness and anthropomorphism (التشبيه), is not veiled by the restrictive tools of time, direction, and place that the verses and reports speak of concerning the Real (الحق) the Exalted. Such as his saying (peace be upon him), "Where is Allah?" and she pointed to the sky, and he affirmed her faith. The Prophet (PBUH) asked using the concept of location (الظرفية) concerning that upon which place is inadmissible according to intellectual consideration, yet the Messenger knows best about Allah, and Allah knows best about Himself. And He said, outwardly: <<أَأَمِنْتُمْ مَنْ فِي السَّمَاءِ>> (Do you feel secure that He who is in the heaven...), and He said: <<وَكَانَ اللَّهُ بِكُلِّ شَيْءٍ عَلِيمًا>> (And Allah is ever Knower of all things), and <<الرَّحْمَنُ عَلَى الْعَرْشِ اسْتَوَىٰ>> (The Most Merciful settled upon the Throne), and <<وَهُوَ مَعَكُمْ أَيْنَ مَا كُنْتُمْ>> (And He is with you wherever you are), and <<مَا يَكُونُ مِنْ نَجْوَىٰ ثَلَاثَةٍ إِلَّا هُوَ رَابِعُهُمْ>> (There is no private conversation of three except that He is the fourth of them). And He rejoices at the repentance of His servant, and He wonders at the youth who has no youthful folly, and similar linguistic tools. It has been established by intellectual proof (البرهان العقلي) that He created times, places, directions, expressions, letters, tools, the speakers of them, and the addressed—all of these are created things (محدثات) belonging to Allah the Exalted. Thus, the Realizer knows definitively that they are directed toward a meaning other than the one that suggests anthropomorphism and similitude, and that the Reality (الحقيقة) fundamentally does not accept that. However, scholars whose doctrines are safe from corporealization (التجسيم) differ in rank. For the anthropomorphists (المشبهة) and corporealists (المجسمة) may be called scholars based on their knowledge of matters other than this. So the scholars differ in their ability to divert the meaning away from this aspect that is inappropriate for the Real (الحق) the Exalted.

### The Difference in Rank Among Scholars Regarding the Meanings of Transcendence

One group neither anthropomorphized nor corporealized, and they referred the knowledge of what came in the speech of Allah and His Messengers back to Allah the Exalted. They did not enter the door of interpretation (التأويل) and were content with mere faith in what Allah knows concerning these expressions and letters, without interpretation or diverting the meaning to any aspect of transcendence. Rather, they said simply, "I do not know," but they rejected the retention of the meaning on the basis of anthropomorphism due to His saying: <<لَيْسَ كَمِثْلِهِ شَيْءٌ>> (There is nothing like unto Him), not due to what intellectual consideration yields. Upon this path are the distinguished traditionists (المحدثين) among the people of the outward (أهل الظاهر) whose doctrines are safe from anthropomorphism and negation (التعطيل).

Another group of those who affirm transcendence (المنزهة) diverted these words away from the aspect inappropriate for Allah the Exalted according to intellectual consideration, diverting them to a specific aspect of transcendence that is intellectually permissible for the Real (الحق) the Exalted to be described by—indeed, He must be described by it. The only remaining consideration is whether that specific aspect is intended by this word or not. That interpretation does not impair His Divinity. They might divert the word to two, three, or more aspects, depending on what the word yields in linguistic usage, but only from the transcendent aspects. If, upon interpreting the report or verse linguistically, they only knew one aspect, they restricted the report to that transcendent aspect and said, "This is it, and nothing else, according to our knowledge and understanding." If they found two or more possible interpretations, they diverted the report or verse to those interpretations. A subgroup of these said, "It is possible that He intended such-and-such, and it is possible that He intended such-and-such," multiplying the transcendent aspects, and then saying, "And Allah knows best which of them He intended." Another group, for whom a certain transcendent aspect was strengthened by some indication (قرينة), definitively restricted the report to that aspect based on that indication, and did not consider the remaining aspects in that report, even though all of them necessitate transcendence.

Yet another group of those who affirm transcendence, who are the highest—and they are among our companions—emptied their hearts of intellectual consideration and speculation, since the preceding groups of interpreters were people of thought, speculation, and investigation. This blessed and successful group arose—and all are successful, praise be to Allah—and said, "The magnification of the Real (الحق), glorious is His Majesty, has been established in our souls such that we cannot reach the knowledge of what has come to us from Him through subtle thought and speculation." In this conviction, they resembled the traditionists whose doctrines were safe, in that they neither speculated, nor interpreted, nor diverted the meaning, but simply said, "We do not understand." Our companions adopted their saying, then moved beyond the rank of these traditionists by saying, "We must follow another method for understanding these words." This is by emptying our hearts of intellectual speculation and sitting with the Real (الحق) the Exalted through remembrance (الذكر) upon the carpet of courtesy (الأدب), contemplation (المراقبة), presence (الحضور), and readiness to accept what comes to us from Him the Exalted, so that the Real (الحق) the Exalted teaches us through Unveiling (الكشف) and Realization (التحقيق), based on what you heard Him say: <<وَاتَّقُوا اللَّهَ وَيُعَلِّمُكُمُ اللَّهُ>> (And fear Allah; and Allah teaches you), and He says: <<إِنْ تَتَّقُوا اللَّهَ يَجْعَلْ لَكُمْ فُرْقَانًا>> (If you fear Allah, He will grant you a criterion [of judgment]), and <<قُلْ رَبِّ زِدْنِي عِلْمًا>> (Say, 'My Lord, increase me in knowledge'), and <<وَعَلَّمْنَاهُ مِنْ لَدُنَّا عِلْمًا>> (And We taught him knowledge from Our presence). When their hearts and aspirations turned toward Allah the Exalted, sought refuge in Him, and cast off what others clung to—the claim of investigation, speculation, and the results of intellects—their intellects were sound and their hearts were purified and empty. When this readiness was present in them, the Real (الحق) disclosed Himself to them as a Teacher. That witnessing (المشاهدة) informed them of the meanings of these reports and words all at once. This is a type of Unveiling (المكاشفة). For when they witness with the eyes of their hearts the One whom the previously mentioned scholars declared transcendent through intellectual perception, it is not possible for them, upon this Unveiling and witnessing, to be ignorant of any of these suggestive reports, nor to leave that report open to all its transcendent possibilities without specification. Rather, they know the word and the transcendent meaning for which it was conveyed, and they restrict it to what was intended for it. And if the exact same expression comes in another report, it has another specific sacred aspect known to this witnesser. This is the state of one group among us. Another group among us does not have this Theophany (التجلي), but they have the casting [of knowledge], inspiration (الإلهام), encounter, and writing. They are protected (معصومون) in what is cast upon them by a sign known only to them, and they inform others of what they were addressed with, inspired with, cast upon them, or written.

It has thus been established among all the Realizers (المحققين)—those who submitted the report to its speaker and neither speculated, anthropomorphized, nor negated; and the Realizers who investigated, strove, and speculated, according to their ranks; and the Realizers who were unveiled and witnessed; and the Realizers who were addressed and inspired—that the Real (الحق) the Exalted is not subject to those restrictive tools of limitation and anthropomorphism in the manner we comprehend them in created things (المحدثات). Rather, they apply to Him based on the meaning of transcendence (التنزيه) and sanctification (التقديس) contained within them, according to the ranks of the scholars and Realizers in that matter, due to what is inherent in them and what His Essence (الذات) necessitates of transcendence. When this is established, it becomes clear that these are tools for communicating to the understanding of the addressed, and every knower understands them according to his comprehension, the strength of his penetration, and his insight. The doctrine of obligation (عقيدة التكليف) is a simple matter; the world was created upon it. If the anthropomorphists (المشبهة) had remained upon what they were created upon, they would not have disbelieved or corporealized, even if they did not intend corporealization. They only intended to affirm Being (الوجود), but due to the deficiency of their understanding, it was only established for them through this imagination (التخيل). Thus, they have salvation.

### The Being of the Real and the Being of the World

Since this has been established among the Realizers, despite the difference in their ranks in the degree of realization, let us say that the realities (الحقائق) grant to those who stand upon them that the Being (وجود) of the Real (الحق) is not restricted in relation to the existence of the World (العالم) by temporal priority, simultaneity, or posteriority. For temporal and spatial precedence concerning Allah—the realities cast this back in the face of the one who asserts it definitively. Unless one asserts it as a means of communication, as the Messenger (PBUH) said and the Book spoke, since not everyone is strong enough for the Unveiling (كشف) of these realities. Thus, nothing remains for us to say except that the Real (الحق) exists by His Essence (بذاته), for His Essence (لذاته), as Absolute Being (مطلق الوجود), unrestricted by anything other than Him, neither caused by anything nor a cause for anything, but rather He is the Creator of causes and effects, the Holy King who has ever been. And that the World (العالم) exists by Allah the Exalted, not by itself nor for itself, its existence being restricted by the Being of the Real (الحق) in its Essence (ذاته). The existence of the World is absolutely invalid except through the Being of the Real. If time is negated from the Being of the Real and from the existence of the World's origin, then the World exists in non-time. Therefore, we do not say, based on the reality of the matter, that Allah exists *before* the World, since it is established that 'before' is a temporal expression, and there is no time. Nor do we say that the World exists *after* the Being of the Real, for there is no posteriority, nor *with* the Being of the Real, for the Real is the One who brought it into existence, and He is its Agent (فاعله) and Inventor (مخترعه), and it was nothing. Rather, as we said, the Real (الحق) exists by His Essence, and the World exists by Him. If a questioner possessed of illusion (وهم) asks, "When was the existence of the World from the Being of the Real?" we say, "When" is a temporal question, and time is from the world of relations (عالم النسب), which is created by Allah the Exalted, because the world of relations has the creation of determination (خلق التقدير), not the creation of origination (خلق الإيجاد). This is a false question, so look carefully at how you ask. Beware lest the tools of communication veil you from realizing and attaining these meanings within yourself. Thus, nothing remains except Pure, Unmixed Being (وجود صرف خالص) that is not from non-existence—which is the Being of the Real (الحق) the Exalted—and existence from non-existence, which is the very essence of the existent—which is the existence of the World. There is no intermediary state (بينية) between the two Beings, nor extension, except for the estimated illusion (التوهم المقدر) that Knowledge (العلم) invalidates and leaves nothing of. Rather, Absolute Being and restricted existence; the Being of the Agent (فاعل) and the existence of the acted-upon (منفعل). This is what the realities have granted. And peace.

### A Question [Applying the Word Invention to the Real]

A spiritual influx (وارد الوقت) asked me about applying the term Invention (الاختراع) to the Real (الحق) the Exalted. I said to him: The Real's Knowledge (علم) of Himself is the very essence of His Knowledge of the World (العالم), since the World has ever been witnessed by Him the Exalted, even though it was characterized by non-existence, and the World was not witnessed by itself, since it was not existent. This is an ocean in which speculators who lack Unveiling (الكشف) have perished. By a relation that has ever existed, His Knowledge has ever existed. And His Knowledge of Himself is His Knowledge of the World, so His Knowledge of the World has ever existed. Thus, He knew the World in its state of non-existence and brought it into existence according to its form in His Knowledge. The explanation of this will come at the end of the book, and it is the secret of Divine Decree (سر القدر) that is hidden from most Realizers. Based on this, Invention is not valid concerning the World, but the term Invention is applied to it in a certain respect, though not from the perspective of what the reality of Invention necessitates, for that leads to a deficiency in the Divine Presence.

True Invention is only valid concerning the servant. This is because the true inventor is not an inventor unless he first invents the paradigm (مثال) of what he wishes to manifest in existence within himself, and then the practical faculty manifests it into sensible existence in the form for which he knows a likeness. If he does not first invent the thing within himself, then he is not truly an inventor. For if you suppose that someone taught you the arrangement of a form that appeared in existence and had a likeness, and you learned it, and then you manifested it into existence as you were taught, you are not, in reality and to yourself, its inventor. Rather, the inventor is the one who invented its paradigm within himself and then taught it to you, even if people attribute the invention to you because they did not witness that thing coming from anyone else. So, return to what you know of yourself and do not pay attention to those who do not know that about you. For the Real (الحق), glory be to Him, did not manage the World as one who acquires what he does not possess or think about, nor is that permissible concerning Him. Nor did He invent within Himself anything that was not already upon Him, nor did He say to Himself, "Should we make it such-and-such?" All of this is inadmissible concerning Him. For the inventor of a thing takes existing parts scattered throughout existents and composes them in his mind and imagination (وهمه) in a composition that was not previously known to him—and even if it was previously known, he does not care, for in that act, he is in the position of the first person whom no one preceded, just as poets and eloquent writers do in inventing novel meanings. There is an invention that has been preceded, and the listener imagines that he stole it. The inventor should not look at anyone except at what originated specifically with him, if he wishes to enjoy and benefit from the pleasure of invention. Whenever the inventor of something looks at someone who preceded him in it after he invented it, he might perish and his liver might burst. The most knowledgeable people in invention are the eloquent, the engineers, and among the craftsmen, the carpenters and builders. These are the people who invent the most, are the sharpest in nature, and the most active in using their intellects. Thus, the reality of Invention is valid for the one who extracts through thought what he did not know before, and what no one else knew, either potentially or potentially and actually, if it is among the sciences whose goal is action.

The Creator, glory be to Him, has ever been Knower of the World eternally, and He was never in a state where He was not Knower of the World. Thus, He did not invent within Himself anything He did not know. Since the eternity (قدم) of His Knowledge is established among the knowers of Allah, it is established that He is our Inventor through the Act (بالفعل), not that He invented our paradigm within Himself—which is the form of His Knowledge of us—since our existence is according to the limit we held in His Knowledge. If it were not so, we would have emerged into existence according to a limit He did not know. And what He does not know, He does not will; and what He does not will and does not know, He does not bring into existence. We would then be existent by ourselves or by chance. If this were the case, our existence from non-existence would be invalid. Yet, the proof indicates our existence from non-existence, and that He knew us, willed our existence, and brought us into existence upon the form established in His Knowledge of us while we were non-existent in our Fixed Entities (أعياننا). Thus, there is no invention in the paradigm. Nothing remains but Invention in the Act (الفعل), and this is sound due to the absence of the paradigm existing in the external entity (العين). Realize what we have mentioned, and after that, say what you wish. If you wish, describe Him by Invention and the absence of the paradigm; and if you wish, negate this from Him—negate it, but only after you have stood upon what I have informed you of.

### The Third Chapter: Knowledge, Knower, and Known (from the Second Book)

> Knowledge, the Known, and the Knower—
> three whose ruling is one.
> And if you wish, their rulings are like them—
> three established by the witnesser.
> But the possessor of the Unseen sees one,
> upon whom there is no addition in loftiness.

Know, may Allah support you, that Knowledge (العلم) is the heart's attainment (تحصيل القلب) of a certain matter according to the limit upon which that matter exists in itself, whether that matter is non-existent or existent. So, Knowledge is the Attribute (الصفة) that necessitates attainment by the heart; the Knower (العالم) is the heart; and the Known (المعلوم) is that attained matter. The conceptualization of the reality of Knowledge (حقيقة العلم) is very difficult, but I will prepare the ground for the attainment of Knowledge by which it will become clear, God willing.

### The Heart and the Divine Presence

Know that the heart (القلب) is a polished mirror, all of it face, which never rusts. If it is ever said that it has rusted, as he (PBUH) said: "Indeed, hearts rust just as iron rusts," and the hadith continues that its polish is the remembrance of Allah (ذكر الله) and the recitation of the Quran. But since it is the Wise Remembrance, the intended meaning of this rust is not an obscurity that has appeared on the face of the heart. Rather, when the heart became attached to and preoccupied with the knowledge of secondary causes (علم الأسباب) instead of the Knowledge of Allah, its attachment to other than Allah became rust upon the face of the heart, because it is the barrier preventing the Theophany (تجلى) of the Real (الحق) to this heart. This is because the Divine Presence (الحضرة الإلهية) is perpetually disclosing Itself; a veil from us is inconceivable concerning It. When this heart did not accept the Divine Presence through the praiseworthy legal address, because it accepted something else, the acceptance of that other thing was expressed as rust, covering, lock, blindness, stain (*rān*), and so forth. Otherwise, the Real (الحق) grants you that Knowledge is with Him, but it is by other than Allah in His Knowledge, while in reality, it is by Allah, according to the knowers of Allah. What supports what we have said is the saying of Allah the Exalted: <<وَقَالُوا قُلُوبُنَا فِي أَكِنَّةٍ مِمَّا تَدْعُونَا إِلَيْهِ>> (And they said, 'Our hearts are covered from that to which you invite us'). So they were covered from what the Messenger specifically invited them to, not that they were in a covering, but rather they became attached to something other than what they were invited to, so they became blind to the perception of what they were called to, and they see nothing. Hearts have ever been created upon clarity, polished and pure. Every heart in which the Divine Presence (الحضرة الإلهية) discloses Itself as the Red Ruby (ياقوت أحمر), which is the Essential Theophany (التجلي الذاتي), that is the heart of the perfect, knowledgeable witnesser (المشاهد المكمل العالم), above whom there is no one in any of the Theophanies. Below that is the Theophany of the Attributes (تجلى الصفات), and below both is the Theophany of the Acts (تجلى الأفعال), but only insofar as they originate from the Divine Presence. As for the one to whom the Divine Presence does not disclose Itself as originating from the Divine Presence, that is the heart heedless of Allah the Exalted, banished from the nearness of Allah the Exalted.

### Conceptualizing the Reality of Knowledge

Look, may Allah grant you success, at the heart according to the limit we mentioned, and see if you make it Knowledge. That is not valid. And if you say it is the essential polish (الصقالة الذاتية) of the heart, there is no way, but it is a cause, just as the manifestation of the Known to the heart is a cause. And if you say it is the cause that attains the Known in the heart, there is no way. And if you say it is the paradigm imprinted in the soul from the Known, which is the conceptualization of the Known, there is no way. If you are asked, "What is Knowledge?" say: It is the perception (درك) of the perceived object according to what it is in itself, provided that its perception is not impossible. As for that whose perception is impossible, Knowledge of it is its non-perception, as Al-Siddīq [Abu Bakr] said: "Inability to perceive perception is perception." Thus, he made Knowledge of Allah to be His non-perception. Know that. But His non-perception is not through the acquisition of the intellect, as others know Him, but rather His perception is through His generosity, grace, and gift, as the Gnostics (العارفون), the people of Witnessing (أهل الشهود), know Him, not through the power of the intellect based on its speculation.

### Completion [Knowledge of Allah through the Cosmos]
